Selected Answer: A
To enroll the Apple iPads in Microsoft Intune using the Apple Configurator enrollment method, you should first configure an Apple MDM push certificate. This certificate is required to establish trust between the iPads and the Intune service, enabling them to enroll and be managed through Intune. After obtaining the MDM push certificate, you can proceed with the enrollment process using the Apple Configurator tool.

comments.content: Configuring EDR Profile is incorrect because it has to be a EDR Policy configured not profile.

Correct, nboarding package for Microsoft Defender is another method to onboard devices to Defender for Endpoint. However, this method is typically used for manual onboarding or when you need to onboard devices that are not managed by Intune.

discussion.content:
You need to create an onboarding package: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/onboarding
Use Intune to automatically deploy it.

Answer IMO is; *Configure: An endpoint detection and response (EDR) profile - you can create this profile and assign it to the group of devices under assignment 
*This is configured in MS Intune

If you create onboarding package then this will be configured in MS Defender portal which is a manual task and the scenario is asking for an automatic solution.
Meaning that given answer is correct.

HOTSPOT

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune and Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.

Users have devices that run Windows 11.

You deploy a connection from Defender for Endpoint to Intune.

You need to ensure that when a device is enrolled in Intune, the device is onboarded automatically to Defender for Endpoint.

What should you configure, and which portal should you use? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Group1: Joined (AzureAD) & Windows -> Device2.
Group2: Registred (Wrokplace) -> Device3.
Device1: ServerAD -> Not in Group1 or Group2.

Based on the above:
NNY

N - It does not fulfill the -eq "AzureAD" because the device is Microsoft Entra Hybrid Joined. 
N - Because the device is has Windows OS type and DeviceTrusttype of AzureAD (Microsoft Entra Joined) but not workplace joined
Y - Device is Entra registered which is equal to Workplace.

N - Y - N 

first 2 are gimmies, but last one is tricky, check this out...

"...(device.deviceTrustType -in ["Hybrid Azure AD joined","Azure AD joined"])
This property applies to:

Windows 11
Windows 10"

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/filters-device-properties

NNN

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/api/resources/device?view=graph-rest-1.0

Type of trust for the joined device. Read-only. Possible values: Workplace (indicates bring your own personal devices), AzureAd (Cloud-only joined devices), ServerAd (on-premises domain joined devices joined to Microsoft Entra ID).

Registered = Personal device

When using deviceTrustType to create dynamic membership groups for devices, you need to set the value equal to

AzureAD to represent Microsoft Entra joined devices, 
ServerAD to represent Microsoft Entra hybrid joined devices or 
Workplace to represent Microsoft Entra registered devices.

Da <https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/users/groups-dynamic-membership>

fo me...

So no one of this can be a group 2 member

device 1 and 2 are member of group 1 (win + azureAD)
device 3 no group (no win but ios +AZureAD)

N

after some research...
device 3 is Azure Ad registered, so devicetrustType -eq "workplace" , so Device 3 is a member of Group 2

so change my answers in 
Y (windows and -eq AzureAD" ) only group 1
N (windows and -eq AzureAD") , only group 1
Y (-eq "workplace") only group 2
I have tested this: iOS are detected by that dynamic rule. So NNY.

Hybrid is not AzureAD, it is ServerAD. TrustType only applies to Windows, iOS are always registered.

For me it is N,N,N.

discussion.content:
IMO
1:NO
2:NO
3:NO
deviceTrustType (Microsoft Entra join type): Create a filter rule based on the device's Microsoft Entra join type. Choose between Azure AD joined, Azure AD registered, Hybrid Azure AD joined, or Unknown values (with -eq, -ne, -in, -notIn operators).

Examples:

(device.deviceTrustType -eq "Azure AD joined")
(device.deviceTrustType -ne "Azure AD registered")
(device.deviceTrustType -in ["Hybrid Azure AD joined","Azure AD joined"])
This property applies to:

Windows 11
Windows 10

comments.content:
• "AzureAD" condition corresponds to Entra-joined devices.
• “Workplace” condition corresponds to Entra-registered devices.
• "ServerAD" condition corresponds to Hybrid Azure AD joined devices (now called Microsoft Entra hybrid joined).
Fully agree. Device1 is Hybrid Joined, so not a member of Group1 (only AzureAD joined devices). IOS cannot have a devicetrusttype, only Windows.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.

You plan to enroll devices in Microsoft Intune.

You need to meet the following requirements:

• Only allow the enrollment of devices that have a specific international mobile equipment identifier (IMEI).
• Support the enrollment and management of up to 1,000 devices.

Which enrollment setting should you configure for each requirement? To answer, drag the appropriate settings to the correct requirements. Each setting may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: Correct, only Device Enrollment Managers can enroll up to 1000 devices.

comments.content:
1. To only allow the enrollment of devices with a specific international mobile equipment identifier (IMEI), you should use:
b. Corporate device identifiers
This setting allows you to identify and pre-declare corporate-owned devices by their IMEI numbers, ensuring that only devices with specific IMEIs can be enrolled.

2. To support the enrollment and management of up to 1,000 devices, you should use:
c. Device enrollment managers
Device enrollment manager accounts can enroll and manage up to 1,000 devices, which meets the requirement for supporting up to 1,000 devices.

discussion.content: Correct
correct

discussion.content: Really tricky question. Why is it indicating its status (Workplace) if it is asking about platform capabilities? If it is asking specifically about those devices in those status, both are Entra Registered only. If they are asking about Windows and iOS in general, the answer is correct.
hybrid needs AD , device1 is in workgroup, so you can't connect ad to azure for hybrid enrollment, because there isn't an ad.

comments.content:
Device1 (Windows 11, workgroup): Microsoft Entra joined or Microsoft Entra registered only.
Device2 (iOS, Not Applicable): Microsoft Entra registered only.

Why does the PC being in a workgroup matter? I can take any computer that is in a workgroup and join it to my AD as long as there is a line of site to a DC. I can also join it to AAD. In this question - all of the infrastructure is in place to accomplish this
But the question status: Which Microsoft Entra join type CAN each device use. Windows CAN be Entra-joined, Hybrid-joined, etc. IOS can not, only registered. I believe answer is correct.

discussion.content: device1 is only in workgroup so no hybrid joined
